Gets a cancellation token related to the original operation that raised the event. It's important for your handler to pass this token along to any asynchronous or long-running synchronous operations that take a token so cancellation (via something like
new CancellationTokenSource(TimeSpan.FromSeconds(10)).Token
for example) will correctly propagate.

remarks.para:
The same event can be raised from both synchronous and asynchronous code paths depending on whether you're calling sync or async methods on a client. If you write an async handler but raise it from a sync method, the handler will be doing sync-over-async and may cause ThreadPool starvation. See
Diagnosing .NET Core ThreadPool Starvation with PerfView for a detailed explanation of how that can cause ThreadPool starvation and serious performance problems.
